svmodt 0.1.0

    • Constructing Oblique Trees with svmodt

    Predict using a Support Vector Machine based Oblique Decision Tree

    svm_predict_tree.Rd

    Predicts class labels or class probabilities for new data using a tree constructed with SVM splits. Handles leaf nodes, internal nodes, recursive traversal, and fallback mechanisms when SVM predictions or scaling fail.

    svm_predict_tree(tree, newdata, return_probs = FALSE, calibrate_probs = TRUE)

    Arguments

    tree

    A tree node object (leaf or internal) created by svm_split.

    newdata

    A data frame of new predictor values.

    return_probs

    Logical; if TRUE, returns both predictions and class probabilities.

    calibrate_probs

    Logical; if TRUE, converts decision values to probabilities using logistic calibration when direct SVM probabilities are unavailable.

    Value

    If return_probs = FALSE, returns a character vector of predicted class labels. If return_probs = TRUE, returns a list with elements:

    • predictions: Character vector of predicted class labels.

    • probabilities: Numeric matrix of class probabilities (rows = samples, columns = classes).

    Details

    - Leaf nodes return the majority class stored in the node, along with class probabilities. - Internal nodes scale features, compute SVM decision values, and traverse left/right children. - Supports binary and multiclass SVMs (one-vs-one decision values for multiclass). - If feature scaling fails or child nodes are missing, predictions are generated using: 1. SVM-provided probabilities. 2. Calibrated decision values (sigmoid/logistic conversion). 3. Training class distribution or uniform probabilities as a last resort. - Probabilities are normalized to sum to 1 for each sample.

    Examples

    if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
preds <- svm_predict_tree(tree, newdata = test_data, return_probs = TRUE)
} # }
